html:
LONDON — Liverpool police detained a man in connection with an incident in which a car was driven through a crowd as thousands celebrated Liverpool’s soccer championship Monday on the city’s streets, sending the celebration into chaos.

Twenty-seven people were taken to hospitals following the incident, which occurred just after 6 p.m. local time. No fatalities have been reported. Two people were seriously injured in the incident, including a child, according to a spokesman for North West Ambulance Service. When emergency services arrived on the scene, four people, including a child, were trapped under the vehicle.

Police detained a 53-year-old British man from the Liverpool area who authorities believe to be the driver of the vehicle. An investigation into the circumstances leading to the collision was underway.

The incident is not being treated as a terrorist act, Jenny Sims, an assistant chief constable with Merseyside Police, said at a news conference Monday evening.

Four children were among the injured. A further 20 people were treated for their injuries at the scene, according to the ambulance service.

Prime Minister Keir Starmer called the incident “appalling” and added, “I want to thank the police and emergency services for their swift and ongoing response to this shocking incident.”

The BBC’s live coverage of the parade showed confusion and chaos at the scene.

“It was so loud. People sounded desperate. And then we looked out the window and we saw the car had run over people,” Natasha Rinaldi, who was watching the parade from a friend’s living room, told the BBC. “We could just hear screams and screams. We were very confused. Some of my friends were down there, and the car was so near them. It was a horrible scene, nobody was expecting it.”

We are in direct contact with Merseyside Police regarding the incident on Water Street which happened towards the end of the trophy parade earlier this evening.

Our thoughts and prayers are with those who have been affected by this serious incident.

We will continue to offer… pic.twitter.com/xreiSqiEnL

— Liverpool FC (@LFC) May 26, 2025

Liverpool clinched the Premier League title last month after a dominant season. At the conclusion of the season Sunday, players hoisted the trophy at the team’s Anfield stadium after a 1-1 tie with Crystal Palace, and they participated in the parade Monday.

Boren reported from Washington.
